4. Cobblers¶

4.1. Introduction¶

Cobblers mend PHP code. They apply a transformation to it.

Cobblers are a complement to code analysis : the analysis spot code to be fixed, the cobbler mends the code. Later, the analysis doesn’t find those issues anymore.

4.2. List of Cobblers¶

4.2.1. Create Phpdoc¶

Create PHPdoc comments for classes, interfaces, traits, methods and functions.

Parameters and return types are collected, along with the name of the structure.

4.2.1.1. Before¶

'<?php

class y {
    function a1(string $error, R $r = null) : int|string
    {

    }
?>

4.2.1.2. After¶

<?php

/**
 * Name : y
 */
class y {
   /**
    * Name : a1
    *
    * string $error
    * null|R $r
    * @return int|string
    *
    */
    function a1(string $error, R $r = null) : int|string
    {

    }
?>

4.2.1.3. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • No anchor for Attributes/RemovePhpdoc

4.2.1.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Attributes/CreatePhpdoc

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.2. Split Property Definitions¶

Split multiple properties definition into independent definitions.

This applies to classes and traits.

4.2.2.1. Before¶

<?php
    class x {
        private $x, $y, $z;
    }
?>

4.2.2.2. After¶

<?php
    class x {
        private $x;
        private $y;
        private $z;
    }
?>

4.2.2.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Multiple Property Declaration On One Line

4.2.2.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Classes/SplitPropertyDefinitions

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.3. Var To Public¶

Replace the var syntax with public keyword.

It is also possible to replace it with protected or private, with the parameter.

4.2.3.1. Before¶

<?php

class x {
    var $y = 1;
}
?>

4.2.3.2. After¶

<?php

class x {
    public $y = 1;
}
?>

4.2.3.3. Parameters¶

Name

Default

Type

Description

var_to_visibility

public

string

The destination visibility to be used. May be one of: public, protected or private.

4.2.3.4. Related Cobblers¶

  • Set Typehints

4.2.3.5. Specs¶

Short Name

Classes/VarToPublic

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.4. Make Static Closures And Arrow Functions¶

Add the static option to closures and arrow functions. This prevents the defining environment to be included in the closure.

4.2.4.1. Before¶

<?php
    $a = function () { return 1; };
    $b = fn () => 2;
?>

4.2.4.2. After¶

<?php
    $a = static function () { return 1; };
    $b = static fn () => 2;
?>

4.2.4.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Could Be Static Closure

4.2.4.4. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • No anchor for Functions/RemoveStaticFromFunction

4.2.4.5. Specs¶

Short Name

Functions/MakeStaticFunction

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.5. Remove Static From Closures And Arrow Functions¶

Removes the static option from closures and arrow functions.

4.2.5.1. Before¶

<?php
    $a = static function () { return 1; };
    $b = static fn () => 2;
?>

4.2.5.2. After¶

<?php
    $a = function () { return 1; };
    $b = fn () => 2;
?>

4.2.5.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Cannot Use Static For Closure

4.2.5.4. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • Make Static Closures And Arrow Functions

4.2.5.5. Specs¶

Short Name

Functions/RemoveStaticFromClosure

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.6. Remove Typehint¶

This cobbler remove the typehint mentions in the code. This might yield some speed when executing, since those tests will be not conveyed at runtime.

Typehints from arguments, method returns and properties are all removed.

4.2.6.1. Before¶

<?php

class x {
    private string $p;

    function foo(D\E $arg) : void {

    }
}

?>

4.2.6.2. After¶

<?php

class x {
    private $p;

    function foo($arg) {

    }
}

?>

4.2.6.3. Parameters¶

Name

Default

Type

Description

type_to_remove

all

data

A comma separated list of types to remove. For example : never,string,ABC;. Use ‘All’ for everyt type.

4.2.6.4. Suggested Analysis¶

  • PHP 8.1 Typehints

4.2.6.5. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • Set Typehints

4.2.6.6. Specs¶

Short Name

Functions/RemoveTypes

Exakat version

2.2.5

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.7. Rename Parameter¶

Change the name of a parameter to a new name.

The destination parameter name is a constant. Suggestions : rename all parameters from the top method (in classes) rename parameters $a into $b (currently, no $a available)

Limits : this cobbler doesn’t check that another parameter is already using that name, nor if a local variable is also using that name. This may lead to unexpected results.

4.2.7.1. Before¶

<?php

foo(a: 1);

function foo($a) {
    return $a;
}

?>

4.2.7.2. After¶

<?php

foo(b: 1);

function foo($b) {
    return $b;
}

?>

4.2.7.3. Parameters¶

Name

Default

Type

Description

oldName

$A

string

The original name of the parameter.

newName

$B

string

The new name of the parameter.

method

string

The name of the target method. Use a full qualified name for a function, and the class name::method for methods.

4.2.7.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Functions/RenameParameter

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.8. Set Null Type¶

Adds a Null type to typehints when necessary.

This cobbler only adds a null type when there is already another type. It doesn’t add a null type when no type is set.

It works on methods, functions, closures and arrow functions. It doesn’t work on properties.

The null type is added as a question mark ? when the type is unique, and as null when the types are multiple.

4.2.8.1. Before¶

<?php

function foo() : int {
    if (rand(0, 1)) {
        return 1;
    } else {
        return null;
    }
}

?>

4.2.8.2. After¶

<?php

function foo() : ?int {
    if (rand(0, 1)) {
        return 1;
    } else {
        return null;
    }
}

?>

4.2.8.3. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • Remove Typehint

4.2.8.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Functions/SetNullType

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.9. Set Type Void¶

Adds the void typehint to functions and methods, when possible

4.2.9.1. Before¶

<?php

function foo() {
    return;
}

?>

4.2.9.2. After¶

<?php

function foo() : void {
    return;
}

?>

4.2.9.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Could Be Void

4.2.9.4. Related Cobblers¶

  • Set Typehints

  • Set Null Type

4.2.9.5. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • Remove Typehint

4.2.9.6. Specs¶

Short Name

Functions/SetTypeVoid

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.10. Set Typehints¶

Automagically add scalar typehints to methods and properties. Arguments and return values are both supported.

When multiple possible types are identified, no typehint is added. If a typehint is already set, no typehint is added.

Magic methods, such as __get(), __set(), __construct(), __desctruct(), etc are not modified by this cobbler.

Methods which have parent’s methods (resp. children’s) are skipped for argument typing (resp return typing) : this may introduce a incompatible definition. On the other hand, methods which have children’s methods (resp. parents’) are modified for argument typing (resp return typing), thanks to covariance (resp. contravariance).

Void (as a scalar type) and Null types are processed in a separate cobbler.

By default, and in case of conflict, array is chosen over iterable and int is chosen over float. There are parameter to alter this behavior.

4.2.10.1. Before¶

<?php

class x {
    private int $p = 2;

    function foo(int $a = 1) : int {
        return intdiv($a, $this->p);
    }
}
?>

4.2.10.2. After¶

<?php

class x {
    private int $p = 2;

    function foo(int $a = 1) : int {
        return intdiv($a, $this->p);
    }
}
?>

4.2.10.3. Parameters¶

Name

Default

Type

Description

array_or_iterable

array

string

When array and iterable are the only suggestions, choose ‘array’, ‘iterable’, or ‘omit’. By default, it is array.

int_or_float

float

string

When int and float are the only suggestions, choose ‘int’, ‘float’, or ‘omit’. By default, it is float.

4.2.10.4. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Could Be Void

4.2.10.5. Related Cobblers¶

  • Var To Public

  • Split Property Definitions

  • Set Null Type

  • Set Type Void

4.2.10.6. Specs¶

Short Name

Functions/SetTypehints

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition, Exakat Cloud

4.2.11. Gather Use Expression¶

Move lone use expression to the beginning of the file

4.2.11.1. Before¶

<?php
    use A;
    ++$a;
    use B;
?>

4.2.11.2. After¶

<?php
    use A;
    use B;
    ++$a;
?>

4.2.11.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Hidden Use Expression

4.2.11.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Namespaces/GatherUse

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.12. Use Available Alias¶

Apply systematically the use expression in the code.

4.2.12.1. Before¶

<?php
    use A\B\C as D;
    new A\B\C();
?>

4.2.12.2. After¶

<?php
    use A\B\C as D;
    new D();
?>

4.2.12.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Could Use Alias

4.2.12.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Namespaces/UseAlias

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.13. Add No Scream @¶

Adds the no scream operator @ to an expression.

4.2.13.1. Before¶

<?php
    $a;
?>

4.2.13.2. After¶

<?php
    @$a;
?>

4.2.13.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • No anchor for Utils/Selector

4.2.13.4. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • Remove Noscream @

4.2.13.5. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/AddNoScream

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.14. Array To Bracket¶

This cobbler updates the array() syntax, and changes it to the bracket syntax.

4.2.14.1. Before¶

<?php
$a = array(1, 2, 3);
?>

4.2.14.2. After¶

<?php
$a = [1, 2, 3];
?>

4.2.14.3. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/ArrayToBracket

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.15. Plus One To Pre Plusplus¶

Transforms a + 1 or - 1 operation into a plus-plus (or minus-minus).

4.2.15.1. Before¶

<?php
    $a = $a + 1;
?>

4.2.15.2. After¶

<?php
    ++$a;
?>

4.2.15.3. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/PlusOneToPre

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition, Exakat Cloud

4.2.16. Post to Pre Plusplus¶

Transforms a post plus-plus (or minus-minus) operator, into a pre plus-plus (or minus-minus) operator.

4.2.16.1. Before¶

<?php
    $a++;
?>

4.2.16.2. After¶

<?php
    ++$a;
?>

4.2.16.3. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/PostToPre

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition, Exakat Cloud

4.2.17. Remove Instructions¶

Removes atomic instructions from the code. The whole expression is removed, and the slot is closed.

This cobbler works with element of a block, and not with part of larger expression (like remove a condition in a if/then, or remove the block expression of a while).

4.2.17.1. Before¶

<?php
    $a = 1; // Code to be removed
    foo(1);

    do          // can remove the while expression
        ++$a;   // removing the block of the do...wihle will generate an compilation error
    while ($a < 10);

?>

4.2.17.2. After¶

<?php
    foo(1);
?>

4.2.17.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Useless Instructions

4.2.17.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/RemoveCode

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.18. Remove Noscream @¶

Removes the @ operator.

4.2.18.1. Before¶

<?php
    @$a;
?>

4.2.18.2. After¶

<?php
    $a;
?>

4.2.18.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • @ Operator

4.2.18.4. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • This cobbler is its own reverse.

4.2.18.5. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/RemoveNoScream

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition, Exakat Cloud

4.2.19. Remove Parenthesis¶

Remove useless parenthesis from return expression.

4.2.19.1. Before¶

<?php
function foo() {
    return (1);
}
?>

4.2.19.2. After¶

<?php
function foo() {
    return 1;
}
?>

4.2.19.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • No Parenthesis For Language Construct

4.2.19.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/RemoveParenthesis

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.20. Rename A Function¶

Give a function with a new name.

This cobbler doesn’t update the name of the functioncalls.

This cobbler may be used with functions, and methods. Functions may be identified with their fully qualified name (i.e. pathfoo) and methods with the extended fully qualified name (i.e. : pathaClass::methodName).

4.2.20.1. Before¶

<?php
    function foo() {

    }
?>

4.2.20.2. After¶

<?php
    function bar() {

    }
?>

4.2.20.3. Parameters¶

Name

Default

Type

Description

name

foo

string

The new name of the function.

4.2.20.4. Suggested Analysis¶

  • No anchor for Utils/Selector

4.2.20.5. Related Cobblers¶

  • Rename FunctionCalls

4.2.20.6. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • This cobbler is its own reverse.

4.2.20.7. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/RenameFunction

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.21. Rename FunctionCalls¶

Rename a function call to another function.

4.2.21.1. Before¶

<?php
    foo(1, 2);
?>

4.2.21.2. After¶

<?php
    bar(1, 2);
?>

4.2.21.3. Parameters¶

Name

Default

Type

Description

origin

strtolower

string

The function name to rename. It will be use lower-cased, and as a fully qualified name.

destination

mb_strtolower

string

The function name to rename. It will be use as is. FQN is possible.

4.2.21.4. Suggested Analysis¶

  • No anchor for Utils/Selector

4.2.21.5. Related Cobblers¶

  • Rename A Function

  • Rename Methodcall

4.2.21.6. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • This cobbler is its own reverse.

4.2.21.7. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/RenameFunctionCall

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.22. Rename Methodcall¶

Rename a method, in a methodcall, with a new name.

This cobbler doesn’t update the definition of the method. It works both on static and non-static methods.

4.2.22.1. Before¶

<?php
    $o->method();
?>

4.2.22.2. After¶

<?php
    $o->newName();
?>

4.2.22.3. Parameters¶

Name

Default

Type

Description

origin

strtolower

string

The function name to rename. It will be use lower-cased, and as a fully qualified name.

destination

mb_strtolower

string

The function name to rename. It will be use as is. FQN is possible.

4.2.22.4. Suggested Analysis¶

  • No anchor for Utils/Selector

4.2.22.5. Related Cobblers¶

  • Rename FunctionCalls

  • Rename A Function

4.2.22.6. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • No anchor for Structures/RemoveMethodCall

4.2.22.7. Specs¶

Short Name

Structures/RenameMethodcall

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

Entreprise Edition

4.2.23. Switch To Match¶

Transforms a switch() into a match() expression.

The switch() syntax must have each of the cases assigning the same variable (or similar). There should not be any other operation, besides break;

4.2.23.1. Before¶

<?php
    switch($a) {
        case 1:
            $b = '1';
            break;
        case 2:
            $b = '3';
            break;
        default:
            $b = '0';
            break;
    }
?>

4.2.23.2. After¶

<?php
    $b = match($a) {
        1 => '1',
        2 => '3',
        default => '0'
    };
?>

4.2.23.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Could Use Match

4.2.23.4. Related Cobblers¶

  • Post to Pre Plusplus

4.2.23.5. Reverse Cobbler¶

  • Remove Instructions

4.2.24. name¶

Fully qualified name of the method to remove. Only one allowed.

4.2.24.1. Before¶

<?php

// removing method \x::method1
class x {
    function method1() {}
    function method2() {}
}

?>

4.2.24.2. After¶

<?php

// removed method \x::method1
class x {
    function method2() {}
}

?>

4.2.24.3. Specs¶

Short Name

Classes/RemoveMethod

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

4.2.25. Remove The Attribute¶

Remove attributes from all supporting structures.

Attributes are located on functions, classes, class constants, properties, methods and arguments.

4.2.25.1. Before¶

<?php

#[Attribute]
function foo(#[AttributeArgument] $arg) {

}
?>

4.2.25.2. After¶

<?php


function foo($arg) {

}
?>

4.2.25.3. Specs¶

Short Name

Attributes/RemoveAttribute

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in

4.2.26. Remove Unused Use¶

Removes the unused use expression from the top of the file. Groupuse are not processed yet.

4.2.26.1. Before¶

<?php

use a\b;
use c\d;

new b();

?>

4.2.26.2. After¶

<?php

use a\b;

new b();

?>

4.2.26.3. Suggested Analysis¶

  • Unused Use

4.2.26.4. Specs¶

Short Name

Namespaces/RemoveUse

Exakat version

2.3.0

Available in
